summary: Black Panther made history last night. The film not only won the first Academy Award ever for Marvel Studios, but also Ruth...
caption:
Black Panther made history last night. The film not only won the first Academy Award ever for Marvel Studios, but also Ruth Carter was the first African-American woman to win for Best Costume Design, and Hannah Beachler was the first woman of color to win (and the first to be nominated) for Best Production Design.

As Diana Mafe (author of Where No Black Woman Has Gone Before: Subversive Portrayals in Speculative Film and TV) says, “When it comes to Black Panther’s Wakanda, the underlying message is that the fictional African nation-state hinges on the agency voices and abilities of black women.”

summary: Polaris, Prisoner X = Gifted, perceived value at Marvel
title: Polaris, Prisoner X = Gifted, perceived value at Marvel
excerpt: Preview from Prisoner X I don’t know how to do a shortcode for a link preview, or if it’s even possible on WordPress with a shortcode, so I’ll just use a link. The above image is …
description:
In this post, I talk mainly about how Prisoner X is clearly a concept taking from Lorna’s use on Gifted (with an old 90s title used for it), but Marvel deciding Lorna shouldn’t get to be the lead or star of Prisoner X shows how little the company thinks of her and interest in her.

And as I say in this post itself: I am not saying Bishop shouldn’t get to be the lead or star of a book. I’m saying he should’ve had something else to be the lead/star of, and it’s wrong that Marvel took an idea that was clearly inspired by recent Lorna used, made another character the star, and made Lorna into a secondary character of a book using a concept she propelled Marvel to use.

title: fall down (to be picked up)
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2BStObI

by LiliaNox, Menatiera

“The angel looked around with obvious disdain on their expression, until their gaze fell upon the throne. Their face fell and their eyes darkened, and anger radiated from them in sickening waves, almost like in sync with the uproar their presence got out of the crowd.

Bucky yelped, and Steve gripped his hair. The situation was tense enough without his newest demon to make it worse.

"An unwanted visit from an upper cousin, what a surprise,” Steve said, his voice sharp as a cut. The murmurs from the rows of demons fell silent immediately. They knew better than to try to talk over their King. “What do you want?”

Steve didn’t expect any of the events to happen, but he had no complains.

—-

Our entry to the 2019 Winterironshield Bang! Fic by Menatiera and gorgeous artwork by the talented LiliaNox!

title: Clint’s Romantic One-Shot
body:
Clint’s Romantic one-shot is live here and on Archive of Our Own (AO3)!

This one-shot was inspired by the song “Drive” by HALSEY.

Please feel free to reblog!

Tag List:

@thoughtsofdarc

Long highways at night are always beautiful. Sometimes creepy, but always beautiful. And this stretch of highway on this particular night is no exception. Few lights meant that stars filled the sky. Your headlights chase them, always losing them just over the horizon of the road. It was hypnotic, soothing. A game you could play forever if the stars stayed in the sky. Unfortunately, you had been driving for hours already and you know you have to pull off soon.

“Tell me again why you wanted to drive back from the mission instead of taking the jet? You know the rest of the team was back at the tower by lunch, right?” Clint shifts his foot on the dashboard of your rental and lolls his head in your direction.

“Feet off the dash,” you grumble.

“Fine fine… sheesh, you’re about as much fun on a road trip as Rogers.”

“You’ve been on a road trip with Steve?” You risk a glance over at him but flick your eyes back to the road almost immediately. There’s no traffic. It’s just too hard to look at Clint in the starlit confines of the car.

“Nope, but Natasha has. She loves to tell that story when Steve’s been a particular pain in her ass.”

You nod, already tuning his voice out. But Clint knows you well. Too well. He reads the exhaustion on your face even in the half-light.

“So c’mon, tell me.” He pokes your shoulder, once. Then again. And again. Finally, he sets up a steady rhythm of pokes, managing to skip a poke every time you try to slap his hand away.

“We’re going to crash and it’ll be your fault.”

“We’re not gonna crash.” Clint rolls his eyes at you, but the poking stops all the same. “But the curiosity will kill me. Why are we on this road trip through the middle of nowhere?”

“You’re here because you ‘wouldn’t hear’ of me taking the trip on my own.”

“Traveling alone is dangerous! It makes you, like, the easiest mark around.”

“I’m an Avenger. I think that disqualifies me as an ‘easy mark’, thank you very much.”

“Not a risk I’m willing to take.” Clint shrugs. His shoulders are loose, relaxed, but his tone is hard. You glance over at him again. He pretends not to notice as he glances out his window and falls silent

Long minutes stretch by. More stars vanish over the horizon in an endless loop of gleaming pinpricks just out of reach. Clint leans forward and fiddles with the radio until you growl at him.

“Let’s make a deal.” Clint turns to lean against his door, one leg tucked up onto the seat as he slips an arm behind his headrest. “I’ll leave the radio alone and stop poking you if you tell me why you opted for land over air.”

You glower at him but he only smiles at you with infuriating calm. A flash of light ahead draws your eyes back to the road and you sigh with relief as you round a bend and a truck stop flares into brilliant existence.

“Salvation.” You breathe the word and make your way off the highway.

“You’re not getting out of this car until you tell me what’s going on with you.” Clint frowns and you don’t even have to look over to confirm it. You can hear it in his voice.

“Watch me,” you snap. And you immediately feel bad. Clint doesn’t know why you’re as upset as you are. He has no idea what being around him does to you now. What it felt like to realize he nearly took a bullet for you today. That you’d nearly lost him. Him and his stupid jokes and his lazy smile and that twinkle in his eyes that you wanted to believe only appeared when you were around.

“Talk to me.” Clint leans toward you and the parking lot lights throw him into sharp relief.

“I’ll pass.”

“Don’t make me do this, {YN}.”

“Do wh-” Your words cut off with a yelp as a dart whistles past your chest and embeds in the door lock.

“Are you fucking serious?” You pull into a parking spot and kill the engine. You tug on the door handle and the door tries to unlock, but the dart is wedged in far enough that it can’t disconnect the mechanism.

“It’s electric too,” Clint adds when you move to pull it from the door.

“Damnit, Clint, disengage the dart and let me out of the car.”

“No, not until you tell me what’s going on. You’ve been acting weird for like a month and then I save your ass on the mission and you get the urge to run off on a road trip. Something is wrong.”

“You didn’t have to do that,” you growl. “You don’t usually catch bullets for anyone else, you didn’t have to do it for me.”

“Yes, I did.” Confusion color’s Clint’s words.

“Why? Why did you come to me instead of Wanda?” You round on him, both hands back on the steering wheel and gripping hard for lack of anything better to do with them.

“Because… because you’re you.” Clint shrugs. Your mouth opens and closes, the answer so vague you don’t even know how to respond.

For a moment you stare at one another. And then, in slow motion, you see some kind of understanding dawn in Clint’s eyes. You curse yourself for not keeping your mouth shut, your face neutral. For trying to outrun the fear of losing him instead of just swallowing it long enough to stay on the jet.

“{YN}-”

“Forget I asked. It’s worth a shock to get out of this muggy car.” You flinch as you wrap your fingers around the dart but nothing happens. Clint starts to speak but you rip it from the door and throw it down the moment you’re out of the car.

“{YN}, wait!” Clint jumps out of the car and calls for you, but you just wave him off and stalk towards the truck stop.

“I need a shower and food. You do you and we’ll meet back up in an hour.”

The clerk behind the counter is star-struck the second you walk in the door.

“You’re… you’re…” He stammers over the words and you force a smile.

“Yep, one and the same. Look, I know the showers are for truckers only but I could really use-”

“On the house!” He slides a key to you across the counter. This time you give him a genuine smile.

“Oh, I’ll pay. I just appreciate getting to use it. Do you guys run tabs here? There’s a bunch of stuff I need to get before I head back out.”

“Anything for a hero!” The guy flushes and pushes a few buttons on his register. “All set, you just go ahead and enjoy yourself, then let me know when you’re ready to cash out.”

“Thank you so much. You just made my day.”

You grab the key and follow the signs that point back to the showers, stopping along the way to grab a few pieces of clothing in nondescript black. Most of the showers are unoccupied and you slip into the one furthest from the register. A quick scan with one of Tony’s devices ensures you’re not being recorded - god only know what SHIELD would go through if a video like that leaked - and you almost groan as you shuck your battle gear. Stark did everything he could to make the stealth suits more comfortable but the materials only gave him so much room to work. After the strain of battle and several hours in the car, it was a relief to let your skin breathe.

The steam builds around you until it blurs the lines of the shower tiles and dulls the faint sounds from the restaurant on the other side of the wall. If you let your eyes slip out of focus the steam almost feels like a wall between you and the world. Between you and Clint. You can’t hear him and you can’t see him. But you know he’s there. You glance at the door and, almost on cue, a faint knock thunk thunks into the steam.

“We need to talk about this.” His voice is impossible to read through the heavy metal door.

“No, we don’t.”

You rinse the last of the soap from your skin and cut the water. Without the shower for white noise, you can suddenly hear everything. Conversations from the restaurant, beeps and rings from the arcade games scattered throughout the building. And Clint’s lockpick in the door.

“I’m naked in here!” You snag a towel from the shelf just outside the shower stall and manage to get it wrapped around the important bits before the bathroom door cracks open.

Steam rushes out as Clint slips in and closes the door behind him. He clicks the lock back into place and leans against the door, his eyes closed.

“I brought you some clothes.” He holds out a bulging plastic bag. Your scowl falters as he jiggles the bag in your general direction, his eyes still closed tight. You wait for a few more heartbeats to see if he peeks, then grab the bag from his fingers.

“Thanks,” you mumble.

Clint nods and leans his head back against the wall, arms folded over his chest. He keeps his eyes closed and you can’t help but take the chance to sneak a few glances at him. Each one lodges your heart in your throat. He knows. He saw it on your face and he knows and there’s no going back from that. You had opted to drive back to New York so that you would have time to get rid of the fear you’d felt on the mission. Fear of losing Clint, of seeing him die. It might have been possible, even with Clint in the car. But there was no getting past the fear now. Not until Clint said what he wanted to say and you said whatever was necessary to get him back in the car and back to New York.

You zip up the hoodie and stuff the bag into one of its pockets as you drop onto a plastic chair in one corner of the room.

“Alright, out with it Barton.” You drag your boots over and start lacing them up. Nothing matches but it ’s clean and comfortable. That’s all you need until you get back to New York.

Clint is silent and you glance up before starting in on your second boot. He’s still leaning against the door, his arms across his chest. His eyes meet yours.

“Are you going to stomp off again? Or do I get to say my piece?” Clint arches one brow. You have the grace to flush faintly as you go back to your boots.

“You’ve got the only exit covered.”

Clint lets loose something between a sigh and a groan.

“I usually love your attitude, but sometimes you’re a real pain in the ass.”

“Right back at ya.” You finish tying your boots and sit back in the chair, one foot bouncing lightly. Most of you wants to book it back to the car but Clint’s in the way. And this isn’t something you can outrun. Especially not when it involves Clint “dog with a bone” Barton.

“Is this why you didn’t want to fly back? Were you…were you trying to get away from me?” Clint’s arms tense across his chest as he puffs himself up and glowers. But for all his bravado he won’t meet your eyes. And that twists your heart around until you almost can’t answer him.

“No,” you choke out. Clint glances at you, still scowling, and you sigh. “Well, I mean…kinda. Yes? I…I…Look, it’s not easy to explain.”

“Try me. It’s not like I haven’t been trying to listen.”

You had to give him that one and your cheeks flush again as you look down at your boots. The words are slow in coming, but you owe him an explanation.

“You are…were…are…oh hell.” You rub one hand over your face, take a deep breath, and try again, forcing your eyes up to his. “You’re my closest friend. Have been for a while. But after a while, I realized that it was…more. To me, at least.”

Clint opens his mouth to speak and you shake your head.

“Just…please, let me finish.”

He closes his mouth, jaw tense. You take another deep breath and lace your hands together to stop the small trembles dancing up and down your fingers. Facing down a Hydra cell was nothing compared to this.

“I didn’t want to ruin things so I didn’t tell you. But you…that bullet…” You stop and close your eyes, heart hammering against your ribs as the memories flood through you once more. The sound of the gun, the blur of Clint’s uniform as he launched himself at you. Both of you going down just barely behind some cover. The bleeding and burned mark across Clint’s ribs where a bullet had grazed him. Close. Too close.

“You could have died saving me.” You can barely manage a whisper and it sounds like nothing next to the bass kick of your heart.

Clint’s hand close around yours. You jump, nearly throwing yourself out of the chair as your eyes snap open. But Clint drags you back into the seat and slips one arm around your waist. He crouches in front of you, jaw tight and eyes hard.

“How long?” He asks. “How long have you felt like this?”

“A couple of months,” you whisper. Clint nods and looks down, his fingers tight around yours.

“And you’re sure? You’re sure you wanna put up with more of my shit? That this is a mess you want to be tangled up with?”

“Like I’m any better?” You can’t help but laugh under your breath. Your heart still rages against your ribs but the banter is so familiar – his touch is so familiar – that you can fake normalcy. At least for the moment.

“You know me, darlin’. I’m a careful person. Can’t go around being reckless.”

Your laugh is so loud and so sudden that it shocks your heart into something closer to a normal rhythm.

“Since when?”

Clint takes your hands in his and laces his fingers through yours.

“Since this is you we’re talking about. Like I said in the car, I risked a bullet because you’re you. If I lost you…” Clint trails off, then shakes his head. “It’s just not an option, okay?”

“So you…I mean…” Your words fade away as Clint smiles up at you.

“Yeah, me too darlin’. For a while now. Nat was sure you felt the same but you seemed so happy as friends. I didn’t want to risk that. Risk you.”

A smile slowly blooms on your lips.

“I know that feeling, Barton. Believe me, I know that feeling.” You let Clint pull you up to your feet, his fingers still interlaced with yours. His gaze lingers on yours for a moment before he pulls you against his chest and releases your hands to wrap you in his arms.

“No more running away, alright? I’d rather plan our next road trip together.”

“Deal.” Your throat feels thick like you’re about to cry, and you bury your face against the cotton of Clint’s shirt. His hands brush down your back as he rests his cheek against the side of your head. You can hear his heartbeat under your ear, feel it against your chest. It’s so close, so loud, that it finally drives away the fear that has been eating at you all day.

He was okay. He was here. And he loved you.
body_abstract:
Clint’s Romantic one-shot is live here and on Archive of Our Own (AO3)!

This one-shot was inspired by the song “Drive” by HALSEY.

Please feel free to reblog!

Tag List:

@thoughtsofdarc

Long highways at night are always beautiful. Sometimes creepy, but always beautiful. And this stretch of highway on this particular night is no exception. Few lights meant that stars filled the sky. Your headlights chase them, always losing them just over the horizon of the road. It was hypnotic, soothing. A game you could play forever if the stars stayed in the sky. Unfortunately, you had been driving for hours already and you know you have to pull off soon.

“Tell me again why you wanted to drive back from the mission instead of taking the jet? You know the rest of the team was back at the tower by lunch, right?” Clint shifts his foot on the dashboard of your rental and lolls his head in your direction.

“Feet off the dash,” you grumble.

“I’ll pass.”

“Don’t make me do this, {YN}.”

“Do wh-” Your words cut off with a yelp as a dart whistles past your chest and embeds in the door lock.

“Are you fucking serious?” You pull into a parking spot and kill the engine. You tug on the door handle and the door tries to unlock, but the dart is wedged in far enough that it can’t disconnect the mechanism.

“It’s electric too,” Clint adds when you move to pull it from the door.

“Damnit, Clint, disengage the dart and let me out of the car.”

“No, not until you tell me what’s going on. You’ve been acting weird for like a month and then I save your ass on the mission and you get the urge to run off on a road trip. Something is wrong.”

“You didn’t have to do that,” you growl. “You don’t usually catch bullets for anyone else, you didn’t have to do it for me.”

“Yes, I did.” Confusion color’s Clint’s words.

“Why? Why did you come to me instead of Wanda?” You round on him, both hands back on the steering wheel and gripping hard for lack of anything better to do with them.

“Because… because you’re you.” Clint shrugs. Your mouth opens and closes, the answer so vague you don’t even know how to respond.

For a moment you stare at one another. And then, in slow motion, you see some kind of understanding dawn in Clint’s eyes. You curse yourself for not keeping your mouth shut, your face neutral. For trying to outrun the fear of losing him instead of just swallowing it long enough to stay on the jet.

“{YN}-”

“Forget I asked. It’s worth a shock to get out of this muggy car.” You flinch as you wrap your fingers around the dart but nothing happens. Clint starts to speak but you rip it from the door and throw it down the moment you’re out of the car.

“{YN}, wait!” Clint jumps out of the car and calls for you, but you just wave him off and stalk towards the truck stop.

“I need a shower and food. You do you and we’ll meet back up in an hour.”

The clerk behind the counter is star-struck the second you walk in the door.

“You’re… you’re…” He stammers over the words and you force a smile.

“Yep, one and the same. Look, I know the showers are for truckers only but I could really use-”

“On the house!” He slides a key to you across the counter. This time you give him a genuine smile.

“Oh, I’ll pay. I just appreciate getting to use it. Do you guys run tabs here? There’s a bunch of stuff I need to get before I head back out.”

“Anything for a hero!” The guy flushes and pushes a few buttons on his register. “All set, you just go ahead and enjoy yourself, then let me know when you’re ready to cash out.”

“Thank you so much. You just made my day.”

You grab the key and follow the signs that point back to the showers, stopping along the way to grab a few pieces of clothing in nondescript black. Most of the showers are unoccupied and you slip into the one furthest from the register. A quick scan with one of Tony’s devices ensures you’re not being recorded - god only know what SHIELD would go through if a video like that leaked - and you almost groan as you shuck your battle gear. Stark did everything he could to make the stealth suits more comfortable but the materials only gave him so much room to work. After the strain of battle and several hours in the car, it was a relief to let your skin breathe.

The steam builds around you until it blurs the lines of the shower tiles and dulls the faint sounds from the restaurant on the other side of the wall. If you let your eyes slip out of focus the steam almost feels like a wall between you and the world. Between you and Clint. You can’t hear him and you can’t see him. But you know he’s there. You glance at the door and, almost on cue, a faint knock thunk thunks into the steam.

“We need to talk about this.” His voice is impossible to read through the heavy metal door.

“No, we don’t.”

You rinse the last of the soap from your skin and cut the water. Without the shower for white noise, you can suddenly hear everything. Conversations from the restaurant, beeps and rings from the arcade games scattered throughout the building. And Clint’s lockpick in the door.

“I’m naked in here!” You snag a towel from the shelf just outside the shower stall and manage to get it wrapped around the important bits before the bathroom door cracks open.

Steam rushes out as Clint slips in and closes the door behind him. He clicks the lock back into place and leans against the door, his eyes closed.

“I brought you some clothes.” He holds out a bulging plastic bag. Your scowl falters as he jiggles the bag in your general direction, his eyes still closed tight. You wait for a few more heartbeats to see if he peeks, then grab the bag from his fingers.

“Thanks,” you mumble.

Clint nods and leans his head back against the wall, arms folded over his chest. He keeps his eyes closed and you can’t help but take the chance to sneak a few glances at him. Each one lodges your heart in your throat. He knows. He saw it on your face and he knows and there’s no going back from that. You had opted to drive back to New York so that you would have time to get rid of the fear you’d felt on the mission. Fear of losing Clint, of seeing him die. It might have been possible, even with Clint in the car. But there was no getting past the fear now. Not until Clint said what he wanted to say and you said whatever was necessary to get him back in the car and back to New York.

You zip up the hoodie and stuff the bag into one of its pockets as you drop onto a plastic chair in one corner of the room.

“Alright, out with it Barton.” You drag your boots over and start lacing them up. Nothing matches but it ’s clean and comfortable. That’s all you need until you get back to New York.

Clint is silent and you glance up before starting in on your second boot. He’s still leaning against the door, his arms across his chest. His eyes meet yours.

“Are you going to stomp off again? Or do I get to say my piece?” Clint arches one brow. You have the grace to flush faintly as you go back to your boots.

“You’ve got the only exit covered.”

Clint lets loose something between a sigh and a groan.

“I usually love your attitude, but sometimes you’re a real pain in the ass.”

“Right back at ya.” You finish tying your boots and sit back in the chair, one foot bouncing lightly. Most of you wants to book it back to the car but Clint’s in the way. And this isn’t something you can outrun. Especially not when it involves Clint “dog with a bone” Barton.

“Is this why you didn’t want to fly back? Were you…were you trying to get away from me?” Clint’s arms tense across his chest as he puffs himself up and glowers. But for all his bravado he won’t meet your eyes. And that twists your heart around until you almost can’t answer him.

“No,” you choke out. Clint glances at you, still scowling, and you sigh. “Well, I mean…kinda. Yes? I…I…Look, it’s not easy to explain.”

“Try me. It’s not like I haven’t been trying to listen.”

You had to give him that one and your cheeks flush again as you look down at your boots. The words are slow in coming, but you owe him an explanation.

“You are…were…are…oh hell.” You rub one hand over your face, take a deep breath, and try again, forcing your eyes up to his. “You’re my closest friend. Have been for a while. But after a while, I realized that it was…more. To me, at least.”

Clint opens his mouth to speak and you shake your head.

“Just…please, let me finish.”

He closes his mouth, jaw tense. You take another deep breath and lace your hands together to stop the small trembles dancing up and down your fingers. Facing down a Hydra cell was nothing compared to this.

“I didn’t want to ruin things so I didn’t tell you. But you…that bullet…” You stop and close your eyes, heart hammering against your ribs as the memories flood through you once more. The sound of the gun, the blur of Clint’s uniform as he launched himself at you. Both of you going down just barely behind some cover. The bleeding and burned mark across Clint’s ribs where a bullet had grazed him. Close. Too close.

“You could have died saving me.” You can barely manage a whisper and it sounds like nothing next to the bass kick of your heart.

Clint’s hand close around yours. You jump, nearly throwing yourself out of the chair as your eyes snap open. But Clint drags you back into the seat and slips one arm around your waist. He crouches in front of you, jaw tight and eyes hard.

“How long?” He asks. “How long have you felt like this?”

“A couple of months,” you whisper. Clint nods and looks down, his fingers tight around yours.

“And you’re sure? You’re sure you wanna put up with more of my shit? That this is a mess you want to be tangled up with?”

“Like I’m any better?” You can’t help but laugh under your breath. Your heart still rages against your ribs but the banter is so familiar – his touch is so familiar – that you can fake normalcy. At least for the moment.

“You know me, darlin’. I’m a careful person. Can’t go around being reckless.”

Your laugh is so loud and so sudden that it shocks your heart into something closer to a normal rhythm.

“Since when?”

Clint takes your hands in his and laces his fingers through yours.

“Since this is you we’re talking about. Like I said in the car, I risked a bullet because you’re you. If I lost you…” Clint trails off, then shakes his head. “It’s just not an option, okay?”

“So you…I mean…” Your words fade away as Clint smiles up at you.

“Yeah, me too darlin’. For a while now. Nat was sure you felt the same but you seemed so happy as friends. I didn’t want to risk that. Risk you.”

A smile slowly blooms on your lips.

“I know that feeling, Barton. Believe me, I know that feeling.” You let Clint pull you up to your feet, his fingers still interlaced with yours. His gaze lingers on yours for a moment before he pulls you against his chest and releases your hands to wrap you in his arms.

“No more running away, alright? I’d rather plan our next road trip together.”

“Deal.” Your throat feels thick like you’re about to cry, and you bury your face against the cotton of Clint’s shirt. His hands brush down your back as he rests his cheek against the side of your head. You can hear his heartbeat under your ear, feel it against your chest. It’s so close, so loud, that it finally drives away the fear that has been eating at you all day.

He was okay. He was here. And he loved you.

This one-shot was inspired by the song “Drive” by HALSEY.

Please feel free to reblog!

“Feet off the dash,” you grumble.

“Fine fine… sheesh, you’re about as much fun on a road trip as Rogers.”

“Nope, but Natasha has. She loves to tell that story when Steve’s been a particular pain in her ass.”

“So c’mon, tell me.” He pokes your shoulder, once. Then again. And again. Finally, he sets up a steady rhythm of pokes, managing to skip a poke every time you try to slap his hand away.

“We’re going to crash and it’ll be your fault.”

“We’re not gonna crash.” Clint rolls his eyes at you, but the poking stops all the same. “But the curiosity will kill me. Why are we on this road trip through the middle of nowhere?”

“You’re here because you ‘wouldn’t hear’ of me taking the trip on my own.”

“Traveling alone is dangerous! It makes you, like, the easiest mark around.”

“I’m an Avenger. I think that disqualifies me as an ‘easy mark’, thank you very much.”

“Not a risk I’m willing to take.” Clint shrugs. His shoulders are loose, relaxed, but his tone is hard. You glance over at him again. He pretends not to notice as he glances out his window and falls silent
